content: this week and make a gnarly looking spooky tree hey guys welcome back to
another episode of black magic crafts for those of you paying attention you
will know that in my home game I am suffering through the sunless citadel
module and I say suffering because I've just come to the realization that I am a
dungeon master who does not like running free made adventures I like making my
own stuff but I started sunless citadel and by golly I'm gonna finish it even if
I change a ton of things along the way if you're familiar with this module you
will know that it ends in an epic showdown beneath a big creepy tree
called the goth iose tree going into this module I thought cool this will be
a fun terrain piece to build but for the past couple months I've been putting it
off because the more I thought about it the more I realized that in order to
build a spooky looking gnarly tree I would have to really step out of my
comfort zone in terms of crafting and materials because while I probably
couldn't make something out of foam it wasn't gonna have the look I really
wanted which meant that I'd have to start experimenting with clay I made a
couple test attempts with some cheap natural air dry clay and they failed
miserably tried making armatures out of tinfoil with some of this clay on top it
shrunk it cracked didn't work so that was out the window I really did not want
to do the wire armature that is really the the nice and the right way to do a
tree cover that in some polymer clay I just was not interested didn't want to
do it I eventually came up with a way to make it and it turned out pretty darn
decent I am quite happy with the way it turned out considering it is not really
in my normal style of crafting but it's always fun to experiment with different
things and step out of your comfort zone so on this episode I am going to build
this Goliath tree let's jump over to the craft table and see how I built it so
based on a recommendation from Luke over at the channel Luke's ApS I decided to
build this thing out of gas modeling clay it is a very affordable air dry
clay and it dry surprisingly hard based on his recommendation I decided to try
the technique that he had shown previously of mixing the - clay with
some regular white PVA glue this will make it even harder I'd like to point
out here that I put in way too much glue which made this one really messy and
annoying to mix but also made it very sticky and difficult to work with but it
made it super hard in the end once my horrible sticky concoction of clay and
glue was mixed up and ready to use I started sculpting and what you can't see
is the air quotes that I'm doing on the word sculpting I really didn't you know
what I was doing at this point I just started to try and make a tree trunk I
realized that the clay on its own before it was cured was very very soft and
bendy and it needed some sort of support so I grabbed a wood dowel and started
building around that and I just kept messing with it and hating myself and my
decision to start this project until I got something that kind of resembled the
shape of a tree trunk again I realized that this clay was way too soft and
malleable to sculpt any sort of tree bark on so I ran out to the yard grabbed
some twigs dug through some snow to find some and I kind of ripped my trunk apart
and put in some branches and started building off the twigs as a sort of
armature finally with an actual somewhat stable
form I was able to get to the part that I was actually looking forward to
doing and that is sculpting the tree bark this was actually fun and was very
easy I just used a little pointed sculpting tool and etched in some lines
it really was not that complicated I didn't really like the base of this
tree it had no definable root structure so I sort of Reese Culp today base and
built it out a little bit more to get some nice hefty roots on which this old
gnarly tree could be standing it was at this point I wondered hmm I wonder how
long this clay is gonna take to dry so I looked at the package in horror when I
realized it said 24 hours per centimeter of clay this tree was very thick and it
was gonna take like a week to dry so I thought it'd be a good idea to cut it
away from the cutting mat I was building it on and raised it up on some pencils
so that hopefully the air could get up underneath into the thicker bottom part
and dry a little bit faster a few days later when the clay was nice and hard I
added some more branches to embellish the tree these were held in place with
some glue and some more das clay and I just sculpted the bases to blend in with
the main trunk I normally don't like putting my terrain pieces on a
decorative base because I like them to be freestanding and not necessarily tied
to any environment but the delicate edges of the clay tree base I thought
could use some protection so I decided to base this on some heavy chipboard I
traced out the footprint of the tree on some chipboard and cut it out and then I
beveled the edge using my exacto knife that's one of the nice things about this
really dense chipboard is you can actually carve it almost like wood I
attached the tree to the base using a whole bunch of hot glue and then I used
some PVA glue and some general purpose sand to decorate the base
I did my usual pre-paint step of Mod Podge and black paint and I don't know
if it was really necessary because this clay dried really dang hard but given
that there was sand clay and natural tree branches involved here the Mod
Podge acted as a nice primer to give me a uniform consistent coating across all
the various materials for painting the first coat of color on this tree was a
brown and you're probably wondering what fancy Brown did I use I used craft smart
acrylic Brown that's the color brown nothingjust
Brown to highlight all of the tree bark texture and to make this thing look
really old and weathered and gnarly I gave the whole thing a dry brushing in a
light tan color using a medium gray I also dry brushed the sandy base to
highlight some of the sand and stones it was important that I used a different
color than the tree bark just so that it didn't all blend together as one big
blob of brown and gray and now the step that takes a very mediocre looking piece
of terrain and turns it into a very halfway-decent looking piece of terrain
the black wash this is the simple homemade black wash that I used on
almost all of my terrain he says if you want to know how to make one of those
check the description I will put a link to the video where I show how to make
this wash to bring back a little bit more of that bark detail and to make
this tree look even more weathered I repeated the tan dry brushing step but
this time I was a lot more careful and I used a lot less paint to make the base a
little bit more dynamic I decided to individually paint out some of the
larger pebbles and stones I completed this base using some static
grass Tufts of the dead grass variety as well as some green flocking I've got a
review on these grass Tufts and I will put a link to that in the description
below if you'd like to purchase any of the tools or supplies that I used in
this video some das clays some chipboard some static grass or flocking you can
head over to Blackmagic crafts dot CA there I have my essential equipment
store where I link to all of the products that I actually use and
recommend purchasing these products on Amazon through my links gives the
channel a small Commission that helps fund these videos another way you can
help out the channel is by supporting Blackmagic crafts on patreon
it is the funds graciously given by my patreon supporters that pay me to make
these videos those donations offset the incredible amount of time and effort it
takes to create these videos and these videos would not exist if it were not
for that support so if you enjoy the videos I make and you want to keep
seeing more of them the best way you can ensure that happens is by helping me out
on patreon I hope you guys found this video useful if you did hit that like
button drop me a comment below and hit that subscribe button if you are not
already a subscriber if you decide to make your own creepy ass tree like I did
I would love to see some photos of it and the best place you can post them is
on the tabletop crafters guild facebook group there's a link in the video
description below if you are not already member and want to join up until next
week guys Cheers happy crafting and happy gaming
